awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigating the nature of dark matter with gravitational lensing
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the nature of dark matter is one of the most pressing issues in all of modern astrophysics.  This mysterious substance makes up the vast majority of the material in galaxies, including our own Milky Way Galaxy, but does not appear in any images taken of these objects.  Furthermore, dark matter is one of the two major components, along with dark energy, that make up the Universe.  While the properties of dark matter are not well known, relatively simple models of it have done a remarkable job of reproducing the distribution of galaxies in the Universe.  However, when looking on smaller scales, the models predict that thousands of small galaxies should orbit galaxies such as the Milky Way, while careful observations of the Milky Way have detected fewer than 50 satellite galaxies.  The primary goal of this project is to build up and analyze a large enough sample of rare gravitational lens systems to distinguish between different models of dark matter and, thus, to further our knowledge about one of the most important components of the Universe.  The excitement of this program will be shared with the public, with a special emphasis on introducing young people to the scientific method and to the techniques of cutting-edge astrophysics research.  This will be accomplished through specialized summer programs for high-school students, introductory-level college classes in astronomy and sustainable energy, and research projects for undergraduates.

The fundamental question underlying this project is "what is the nature of dark matter?".  We now know that dark matter is a major component of the mass energy of the Universe, second only to dark energy, and completely dominates the mass of galaxies and galaxy clusters.  However, the properties of the dark matter particle are not well quantified with efforts to measure these properties proceeding both in astrophysics and physics.  The proposed research utilizes four steps to better understand dark matter: (1) building better statistics by applying our gravitational imaging and flux-ratio anomaly techniques to new samples that will provide a significant increase over our current numbers, (2) significantly improving the power of the lensing approach to disentangle cold and warm dark matter by pushing orders of magnitude down the mass function of substructures, (3) develop techniques to reduce systematic errors that are now known to have affected earlier dark matter analyses, and (4) do at least two independent measurements of the substructure mass function in distant galaxies and analyze the results in the context of alternative dark matter models.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

 

The fundamental question underlying this proposal is ``what is the nature of dark matter?''. We now know that dark matter is a major component of the Universe, second only to dark energy, and completely dominates the mass of galaxies and galaxy clusters. However, the properties of the dark matter particle are not well known, with efforts to measure these properties proceeding both in astrophysics and physics. One clear test of the properties of dark matter is the statistics of structure formation in the Universe. Observations of large-scale structure match the prediction of the standard cold dark matter paradigm (CDM). However, on smaller scales, searches for Local Group satellite galaxies (luminous ``substructure'') reveal many fewer than predicted, suggesting some tension with the CDM model. This program used a technique called strong gravitational lensing to obtain better statistical measurements of dark matter substructure, and to search for significant deviations from CDM that may be due to, e.g., warm dark matter.

 

Intellectual Merit:

 

Strong gravitational lensing is a powerful tool for this investigation because it can locate and measure the masses of substructure without requiring the substructure to be luminous, and it can do these detections for galaxies well outside the Local Group, allowing much better statistical samples to be constructed. The program achieved the following outcomes: (1) built better statistics by applying our gravitational imaging and flux-ratio anomaly techniques to new samples, providing a significant increase over our current numbers; (2) achieved the most stringent limits to date on the “free streaming length” of  dark matter, ruling out some forms of warm dark matter and verifying a fundamental prediction of standard CDM, using multiple independent datasets; (3) developed techniques to test alternative models of dark matter, including self-interacting dark matter; (4) measured for the first time the concentration mass relation of dark matter subhalos, finding results consistent with the predictions of standard CDM; (5) measured for the first time the primordial matter power spectrum at scales much smaller than those probed by the cosmic microwave background.

 

Broader Impacts:

Treu developed and taught a general education course ``The physics of sustainable energy'', aimed at illustrating to students the scientific method and improving the use of quantitative thinking into the environmental debate.  Treu mentored Cal State students through the CALBRIDGE program, aimed at improving admission rates into top graduate programs for students members of under-represented groups. Two UCLA graduate students have been trained in cutting edge data analysis and in the use of the most powerful telescopes. In parallel with the human effort, Treu continued his efforts to develop new instrumentation, with an emphasis on adaptive optics (AO) capabilities for Keck and the future generation of extremely large telescopes. The experience gathered during this research program will help optimize these facilities and thus maximize benefit to the entire community of users.
